questions.text:
A 55-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension is brought to the emergency department after collapsing at home. On examination, he is found to be unresponsive with agonal breathing. His pulse is weak and thready, and his pupils are dilated and non-reactive to light. The emergency team initiates advanced cardiovascular life support protocols.

 

Question: In the context of acute management, which of the following is NOT considered a primary component of the "Bishop’s triad of life" that must be rapidly assessed and managed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Genitourinary function.

 

Explanation:

 

The bishop’s triad of life, often referred to in emergency medicine, consists of the three critical components that are vital to sustain life: circulation, respiration, and neurological function. These components must be rapidly assessed and managed in an unresponsive patient.

 

Genitourinary function, while important, is not considered a primary component that requires immediate assessment in a life-threatening or emergency situation.

 

The question of somatic death is important in resuscitation and organ transplantation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bishop’s tripod of life is circulation, respiration, and brain function. Complete and irreversible stoppage of any one component from bishop’s tripod cause somatic death.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 134

questions.text: A 32-year-old male is brought to the emergency department following a severe motorcycle accident. He sustained a high cervical spinal injury and traumatic brain injury. On examination, the patient is comatose, with no spontaneous respirations observed when taken off the ventilator for a brief period. Pupils are fixed and dilated, and there is no gag or corneal reflex. The trauma team considers using the Minnesota criteria to determine the prognosis. According to the Minnesota criteria, what is the primary determination to be made in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brainstem death.

 

Explanation:

 

The Minnesota criteria are a set of guidelines that are specifically used to determine brainstem death. These criteria focus on the absence of brainstem reflexes, no spontaneous movements, apnea, and irreparable intracranial lesions.

 

The criteria stipulate that these findings must remain unchanged for at least 12 hours to pronounce brainstem death. In the vignette, the patient's fixed and dilated pupils, lack of gag or corneal reflex, and apnea when taken off the ventilator point towards the cessation of brainstem function, which is consistent with brainstem death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Minnesota criteria (1971) - to identify brainstem death.
  • Harvard’s Criteria - for Cortical brain death.
  • Philadelphia Protocol (1969) - for brain stem death

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 134-135

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a known history of epilepsy is found unresponsive in his home. Emergency services were called, and upon their arrival, the patient was pronounced dead. The body showed no signs of trauma, and there was no evidence of seizure activity. The patient's medical history is significant for poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. An autopsy is performed to determine the cause of death. In the autopsy findings, which of the following conditions is least likely to be the cause of a 'negative autopsy'?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diabetes mellitus.

 

Option D:

 

  • A negative autopsy is one where the post-mortem examination fails to reveal a clear anatomical cause of death. Vagal inhibition, laryngeal spasm, and status epilepticus are conditions that can lead to death without leaving significant anatomical changes, making them potential causes of a negative autopsy.
  • Diabetes mellitus, while it can lead to a sudden death, is often associated with significant anatomical findings such as changes in the pancreas, evidence of end-organ damage like nephropathy, retinopathy, or neuropathy, or could lead to fatal events like myocardial infarction which are usually identifiable during an autopsy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vagal inhibition can cause a sudden cardiac arrest, which might not leave any anatomical trace detectable in an autopsy.

 

Option B. Laryngeal spasm can lead to asphyxiation, which may not present with specific anatomical findings post-mortem.

 

Option C. Status epilepticus, particularly in the postictal state, can result in sudden unexplained death in epilepsy (SUDEP) without anatomical correlates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Negative autopsy includes acute events that do not result in discernible anatomical changes, as opposed to chronic conditions like diabetes mellitus which usually produce significant anatomical evidence of disease.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 143

questions.text: A 63-year-old male with a history of hypercholesterolemia and smoking presents to the emergency department with chest pain that started while he was mowing the lawn. The pain is described as a pressure sensation on his chest with radiation to his left arm. An ECG shows ST-segment elevations. Considering the most common location for myocardial infarctions, which area of the heart is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior wall of left ventricle.

 

Option A:

 

  • The anterior wall of the left ventricle is the most common site of myocardial infarctions, often due to occlusion of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery.
  • Clinical presentation with chest pain radiating to the left arm and ST-segment elevations on ECG is highly suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction affecting this region.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Posterior wall infarctions of the left ventricle are less common and typically involve occlusion of the right coronary artery or the circumflex artery.

 

Option C. Anterior wall infarctions of the right ventricle are rare and would more commonly present with hemodynamic instability due to the right ventricle's involvement in preload dependence.

 

Option D. Infarctions of the interventricular septum can occur but are most commonly associated with anterior wall myocardial infarctions, as the septum is usually supplied by the LAD artery as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior wall of the left ventricle is the most common site of myocardial infarctions, often associated with occlusion of the LAD artery.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 145

questions.text: You are a resident performing a postmortem examination under the supervision of the medical examiner. The body of a recently deceased individual shows several physiological changes. As part of your training, you are asked to identify the findings that are not typically associated with the early postmortem period. Which of the following is not considered an early sign of death?
questions.solution:
Ans C) Loss of voluntary power

 

Option C:

 

  • Loss of voluntary power is the immediate sign of death. whereas question is asking about "early" sign of death.

 

CHANGES AFTER DEATH

A) Immediate Changes

  • Insensibility and no response to stimuli
  • No spontaneous respiration
  • No spontaneous cardiac activity

 

B) Early Changes

  • Skin- earliest early change
  • Eyes
  • Algor mortis
  • Livor mortis
  • Rigor mortis

 

C) Late Changes:

  • Putrefaction
  • Adipocere
  • Mummification

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Corneal opacity (early sign) can occur shortly after death due to dehydration of the corneal epithelium. The opacity is due to drying and is delayed for about two hours if the lids are closed after death.

 

If the eyelids are open for a few hours after death, a film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera at each side of the iris, with base towards the margin of cornea and apex towards medial or lateral canthus of the eye, which become brown and then black called "tache noir" within 3 to 4 hours, upon which dust settles and the surface becomes wrinkled (artefact)

 

 

Option B. Loss of elasticity of skin (early sign) - Skin becomes pale and ashy-white and loses elasticity within a few minutes of death. The lips appear dark-red to black, dry and hard due to drying.

 

Option D. Postmortem cooling/ Algor mortis (early sign) - refers to the body cooling down to match the ambient temperature after death, which begins as soon as circulatory and respiratory functions cease.

 

Rate of cooling is 0.4 to 0.6°C per hour for next 12 to 16 hours after death. In tropical climates the heat loss is roughly 0.4 to 0.6°C and in temperate countries 1°C per hour.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signs of death appear in the following order:

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 152

choices.text: The patient has a reduced metabolic rate.
The patient cannot be revived by resuscitation.
The oxygen requirement of individual cells is satisfied through dissolved oxygen in the blood.
A yogic person can remain in suspended animation.

questions.text: During your duty hours in the emergency department, paramedics bring in a 60-year-old male who was found unconscious in a cold environment. He has a history of practicing meditation and yoga. His body temperature is significantly below normal limits, and he appears to be in a state of suspended animation. You initiate rewarming procedures and prepare for resuscitation. Which of the following statements is false regarding the state of suspended animation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The patient cannot be revived by resuscitation.

 

Option B: Resuscitation is successful. The patient can be resuscitated by cardiac massage or electric stimulator and artificial respiration.

 

Explanation:

 

SUSPENDED ANIMATION (Apparent Death)

 

  • In this condition signs of life are not found, as the functions are interrupted for some time, or are reduced to a minimum.
  • Metabolic rate is so reduced (option a) that the requirement of individual cell for oxygen is satisfied through the use of oxygen dissolved in the body fluids. (Option c)
  • Suspended animation may be produced voluntarily as in Yoga Practitioners (option d)
  • Involuntary suspension of animation lasting from a few seconds to half-an-hour or more may be found in vagal inhibition, severe syncopal attacks, newborn infants, drowning, electrocution, sunstroke, cholera, narcotic poisoning, after anesthesia, shock, hypothermia, cerebral concussion, insanity, etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suspended animation is a reversible state, and patients can often be resuscitated with appropriate medical intervention.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 152

questions.text: As a resident in the emergency department, you are presented with a patient who has been found unconscious. There are no signs of trauma, and the patient has a weak pulse. You need to quickly assess the patient's respiratory status using bedside tests before deciding on further management. Which of the following tests is not typically used to assess respiration in an unresponsive patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Magnus test

 

Option D:

 

  • Magnus test/ Ligature Test (1872) - Tying a string around one of the fingers with a pressure just above venous pressure and below pressure in arteries. If the circulation is maintained finger distal to ligature would swell.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Feather test - A quick bedside method to see if the patient is breathing by observing for movement caused by exhaled air.

 

Option B. Mirror test - Uses the appearance of fog on a mirror to indicate the presence of exhaled breath, thus confirming respiration.

 

Option C. Winslow's glass water test - No movement of reflection of light shone on mirror, or surface of water in bowl, kept on the chest/ abdomen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tests for circulation: Magnus test (ligature test), I card test (Fluorescin test), Diaphanous test (transillumination test), fingernail test.

 

Tests for respiration: Winslow's test, mirror test, feather test.

 

These tests for circulation and respiration are obsolete now.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 152

questions.text: During a routine review, a forensic resident discusses the phenomenon of postmortem caloricity, which can be observed in several conditions due to continued metabolic activity or external factors. Which of the following conditions is not typically associated with postmortem caloricity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Barbiturate poisoning

 

Option D:
 

Postmortem caloricity, characterized by elevated body temperature after death. In this condition, the temperature of the body remains raised for the first two hours or so after death.

 

This occurs:

 

  1. When the regulation of heat production has been severely disturbed before death, as in sunstroke and in some nervous disorders,
  2. When there has been a great increase in heat production in the muscles due to convulsions, as in tetanus and strychnine poisoning, etc., and
  3. When there has been excessive bacterial activity, as in septicemic condition, cholera, and other fevers

 

Barbiturate poisoning usually leads to central nervous system depression and would not cause increased metabolic activity after death.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sunstroke causes the body to overheat and can maintain elevated temperatures postmortem.

 

Option B. Strychnine poisoning involves convulsions and muscle activity that generate heat.

 

Option C. Septicemia can lead to fever due to infection, and this may persist for some time after death.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Postmortem caloricity is observed in conditions like sunstroke, strychnine poisoning, and septicemia, where elevated body temperature may persist after death, but not typically with barbiturate poisoning, which depresses metabolic activity.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 155

questions.text: A 72-year-old man, with a history of chronic heart failure, was found unresponsive in his home. He was pronounced dead upon the arrival of emergency services. During the autopsy, the forensic pathologist notes a bluish-purple discoloration in the dependent areas of the body. The pathologist explains to the medical students that this is a common postmortem change known as livor mortis or postmortem lividity. He asks the students about the primary cause of this color change. What is the most likely Explanation for this discoloration?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deoxyhaemoglobin

 

Option B:

 

  • Postmortem lividity, also known as PM staining (PMS), Suggillation, Vibices, or livor mortis, is due to the pooling of blood in the dependent parts of the body (capillovenous distension.), which leads to the accumulation of deoxygenated blood.
  • The bluish-purple coloration is characteristic of deoxyhaemoglobin, which is hemoglobin that is not bound to oxygen.

 

 

Important Pointers –

 

  • Postmortem lividity is an Early sign of death
  • It usually begins shortly after death, well developed within 4 hours after death and reaches a maximum between 6 to 12 hours.
  • Postmortem lividity gets fixed after 6 hours (Primary lividity) and persists until putrefaction sets in. Hence before fixation of lividity, if the body is moved to a new place, then the lividity will appear in the dependent parts of new position (Secondary lividity).
  • The intensity of postmortem lividity depends on the amount of circulating blood volume, hence less marked in death due to hemorrhage, anemia, wasting disease.
  • PML will not appear if there is >65% blood loss in adults and 45% in children
  • Lividity is more intense in asphyxia death, sudden death

 

Explanation:


Option A. Oxyhaemoglobin - Is bright red as it reflects oxygenated blood, which would not cause a bluish-purple color.

 

Option C. Methaemoglobin - Is a form of hemoglobin that is oxidized and unable to carry oxygen effectively, and it can affect the color of the blood. 

 

Option D. Sulphmethaemoglobin forms when hydrogen sulfide (from putrefaction) reacts with hemoglobin.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The bluish-purple color of postmortem lividity is due to deoxyhaemoglobin from the pooling of deoxygenated blood in the dependent areas of the body after death.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 155

choices.text: Traumatic injury from a road traffic accident
Sudden cardiac arrest while eating (Café coronary syndrome)

questions.text: During a routine autopsy, an unidentified body presented with a unique pattern of postmortem lividity: a distinct bluish-purple discoloration confined to areas that would be covered by gloves and stockings. The forensic pathologist must determine the most likely cause of death. Which scenario is most consistent with this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Venous congestion from hanging.

 

Option C:

 

  • The 'Glove and Stocking' lividity pattern is indicative of blood pooling in the extremities while the body is suspended in an upright position.
  • This pattern can occur in hanging, where the head and torso are above the legs, allowing gravity to pull the blood down into the arms and legs, creating this distinct pattern.
  • The pressure of a noose around the neck or tight clothing on the body can prevent lividity in those areas, thus resembling gloves and stockings.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Asphyxiation by drowning - typically leads to uniformly distributed lividity due to the body lying in a horizontal position in water, which would not create a 'glove and stocking' pattern.

 

Option B. Traumatic injury from a road traffic accident can cause a variety of injuries, and while it may result in lividity, the pattern would generally not be restricted to areas resembling gloves and stockings unless the body was left in a position that would allow for such a pattern to emerge.

 

Option D. Sudden cardiac arrest while eating, or Café coronary syndrome, results from an obstruction of the airway leading to asphyxia. Postmortem lividity in these cases would depend on the position of the body following the event and would not specifically lead to a 'glove and stocking' pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 'glove and stocking' pattern of postmortem lividity as a sign most consistent with venous congestion from hanging.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 167

questions.text: A 65-year-old male was found deceased in his apartment on a hot summer day. The medical examiner arrived and estimated the time of death to be approximately two days prior. Upon examination, the body showed a well-defined postmortem lividity. The medical examiner explained to the residents that postmortem lividity can persist until a certain event occurs in the decomposition process. Until what point does postmortem lividity typically persist?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Putrefaction sets in

 

Explanation:

 

  • Postmortem lividity is an Early sign of death
  • It usually begins shortly after death, well developed within 4 hours after death and reaches a maximum between 6 to 12 hours.
  • Postmortem lividity gets fixed after 6 hours (Primary lividity) and persists until putrefaction sets in. Hence before fixation of lividity, if the body is moved to a new place, then the lividity will appear in the dependent parts of new position (Secondary lividity).
  • The intensity of postmortem lividity depends on the amount of circulating blood volume, hence less marked in death due to hemorrhage, anemia, wasting disease.
  • PML will not appear if there is >65% blood loss in adults and 45% in children
  • Lividity is more intense in asphyxia death, sudden death

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postmortem lividity persists until the onset of putrefaction, which disrupts the lividity due to the bloat and decay processes.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 156

choices.text: Prolonged exposure to a cold environment leading to hypothermia
Exposure to high levels of carbon monoxide
Acute nitrite poisoning leading to methemoglobinemia

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is reviewing a case for a teaching session with medical students. The victim, a hiker, was found deceased in the mountain at high altitude. The autopsy revealed a pink coloration to the postmortem lividity, which the pathologist is using to illustrate the physiological changes associated with the cause of death. What is the most likely cause of the pink discoloration in postmortem lividity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prolonged exposure to a cold environment leading to hypothermia

 

Option A:

 

The pink coloration of postmortem lividity is characteristic of deaths due to hypothermia. In cold environments, the lower temperature preserves the hemoglobin in red blood cells, which can cause the lividity to appear pink. Additionally, the cold inhibits bacterial growth and decomposition, further contributing to the maintenance of the pink color.

 

Given that the victim was found at high altitude—a setting commonly associated with low temperatures—hypothermia is the most likely cause.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Exposure to high levels of carbon monoxide would result in a cherry-red coloration of the postmortem lividity due to the formation of carboxyhemoglobin. Although similar in appearance to the pink seen in hypothermia, carbon monoxide poisoning often occurs in enclosed spaces or in the context of fires. The scenario does not mention any indication of fire or enclosed combustion, making this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option C. Cyanide poisoning can also result in a bright red or pinkish postmortem lividity, as cyanide inhibits cellular respiration, leading to high oxygen content in the blood. However, cyanide exposure is typically associated with industrial accidents, ingestion, or fires—none of which are mentioned in the scenario. Thus, it is an unlikely cause in this context.

 

Option D. Acute nitrite poisoning would lead to the formation of methemoglobin, which would give the postmortem lividity a chocolate brown color.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Medicolegal importance: Nature of poisoning and color of postmortem lividity -

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 318

choices.text: Cardiac muscles - Muscles of the eyelids - Jaw muscles - Muscles of the upper limbs - Chest  muscles - Muscles of the lower limbs
Cardiac muscles - Muscles of the eyelids - Jaw muscles - Chest muscles - Muscles of the upper limbs - Muscles of the lower limbs
Muscles of the eyelids - Cardiac muscles - Chest muscles - Muscles of the lower limbs - Muscles of the fingers and toes
Muscles of the fingers and toes - Muscles of the eyelids - Jaw muscles - Abdominal muscles - Muscles of the upper limbs - Muscles of the lower limbs

questions.text: A group of medical students is discussing the physiology of rigor mortis with their instructor. They are trying to determine the correct sequence of muscle stiffness post-mortem. Which of the following represents the correct order of rigor mortis appearance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cardiac muscles - Muscles of the eyelids - Jaw muscles - Chest muscles - Muscles of the upper limbs - Muscles of the lower limbs

 

Explanation:

 

Rigor mortis (death stiffening; cadaveric rigidity) is a state of stiffening of muscles, sometimes with slight shortening of the fibers. Individual cell death takes place in this stage.

 

The Order of Appearance of Rigor: All muscles of the body, both voluntary and involuntary are affected. It does not start in all muscles simultaneously (Nysten's rule). It first appears in involuntary muscles; the myocardium becomes rigid in an hour. It begins in the eyelids, neck and lower jaw and passes upwards to the muscles of the face, and downwards to the muscles of the chest, upper limbs, abdomen, and lower limbs and lastly in the fingers and toes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nysten’s rule: It deals with the progression of rigor in different muscles. Rigor develops both in voluntary and involuntary muscles. It first appears in involuntary muscles such as myocardium and then in eyelid muscles, neck and lower jaw and passes upwards to the muscle of face, and downwards to the muscles of chest, upper limbs, abdomen, and lower limbs, and lastly in the fingers and toes.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 161

choices.text: Heat stiffening due to high environmental temperatures
Cadaveric spasm resulting from intense antemortem muscle activity
Heat rupture as a result of thermal injury to the muscles
Gas stiffening due to bacterial activity and gas formation

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is conducting a seminar on postmortem changes and presents a case to the medical students. The case involves a body found in a desert region. The pathologist notes that there are conditions that can mimic the stiffening observed in rigor mortis and asks the students which of the following conditions does not typically simulate rigor mortis.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heat rupture as a result of thermal injury to the muscles

 

Option C:

 

Heat rupture is a condition where muscles are damaged due to intense heat, causing them to split or rupture, showing irregular margin. This does not cause stiffening. It usually resembles the lacerated wound.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Heat stiffening is caused by the coagulation of body proteins due to high environmental temperatures and can mimic the stiffening seen in rigor mortis.

 

Option B. Cadaveric spasm is a form of instantaneous rigor mortis that occurs at the moment of death, is typically associated with violent deaths, and can mimic the stiffening seen in rigor mortis.

 

Option D. Gas stiffening results from bacterial activity and gas formation within the body, leading to a rigidity that can resemble rigor mortis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While heat stiffening, cadaveric spasm, and gas stiffening can mimic rigor mortis, heat rupture is a condition that results from thermal injury to muscles and does not cause stiffening that simulates rigor mortis.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 323

questions.text: A medical student is participating in a forensic medicine workshop. The instructor presents a case where a body was discovered in a desert environment. The student is asked to determine the minimum environmental temperature at which heat stiffening of the body could occur. Which temperature threshold is most likely to lead to heat stiffening?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 65°C

 

Explanation:

 

Heat Stiffening:

 

  • When a body is exposed to temperatures above 65°C. a rigidity is produced, which is much more marked than that found in rigor mortis.
  • The degree and depth of the change depends on the intensity of the heat and the time for which it was applied. It is seen in deaths from burning, high voltage electric shock and from falling into hot liquid.
  • Heat causes stiffening of the muscles, because the tissue proteins are denatured and coagulated as in cooking.
  • The muscles are contracted, desiccated, or even carbonized on the surface. A zone of brownish pink 'cooked meat', is seen under this, overlying normal red muscle. Changes in posture, especially flexion of the limbs occur due to muscle contraction. The stiffening remains until the muscles and ligaments soften from decomposition and the normal rigor mortis does not occur.

 

Note - Cold Stiffening: When a body is exposed to freezing temperatures (-5°C  or lower) before acid metabolites appear in the muscles, the tissues become frozen and stiff, due to freezing of the body fluids and solidification of subcutaneous fat simulating rigor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heat stiffening >65°C and Cold stiffening -5°C or lower

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 163

choices.text: Molecular death is not a component of cadaveric spasm.
Cadaveric spasm typically involves only a single group of muscles.
Muscles affected by cadaveric spasm go through an initial stage of relaxation before spasming.
Cadaveric spasm can assist in determining the manner of death.

questions.text: A professor is discussing the nuances of postmortem changes with medical students. They explore the concept of cadaveric spasm, a phenomenon that is often confused with rigor mortis. The professor notes that one of the statements below is incorrect regarding cadaveric spasm. Which one is it?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Muscles affected by cadaveric spasm go through an initial stage of relaxation before spasming.

 

Option C:

 

Cadaveric spasm is a form of instantaneous rigor mortis that occurs at the moment of death and involves the immediate stiffening of muscles without a prior stage of relaxation. It is believed to occur in sudden deaths, particularly those associated with intense emotion or physical activity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This is true; molecular death refers to the cessation of biological functions at the cellular and molecular levels, which is not directly related to the mechanical phenomenon of cadaveric spasm.

 

Option B. This is true; cadaveric spasm often affects an isolated group of muscles and is sometimes seen clutching objects or in a position indicative of the individual's activity at the moment of death.

 

Option D. This is true; cadaveric spasm can sometimes provide insights into the circumstances surrounding death, especially if the deceased is found clutching something or in a defensive posture, suggesting a struggle or sudden, intense activity at the time of death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cadaveric spasm is an immediate stiffening of muscles now of death without an initial relaxation phase and can provide clues about the manner of death.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 162

questions.text: A forensic pathology instructor shows medical students an image of a cadaver exhibiting a network of greenish-brown or purplish-red discoloration in a linear branching pattern, commonly known as marbling. The students learn that this results from the formation of sulph-hemoglobin within the vessels due to hemolysis of red cells. They are then questioned about the timeframe in which this change typically begins to manifest postmortem. Based on the provided description, when does the marbling of the skin start to become prominent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 24-36 hours

 

Explanation:

 

Marbling of Skin:

 

  • The superficial veins especially over the roots of the limb, thighs, sides of the abdomen, shoulders, chest and neck are stained greenish-brown or purplish-red depending on the total amount of sulphhaemoglobin formation within the affected vessels (linear branching pattern) due to the haemolysis of red cells, which stains the wall of the vessel and infiltrates into the tissue, giving a marbled appearance (red, then greenish pattern in skin resembling the branches of a tree) This starts in 24 hours, but is prominent in 36 to 48 hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marbling of the skin, a postmortem change due to sulphhemoglobin formation, typically starts within the first 24 hours postmortem and becomes prominent by 36 to 48 hours.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 165-166

questions.text: During a forensic pathology seminar, the medical examiner presents various organs to the residents and asks them to identify which organ typically shows the earliest signs of putrefaction after death. Based on the provided sequence, which organ should the residents identify as the first to undergo putrefactive changes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Larynx

 

Explanation:

 

Given the provided order of appearance of putrefaction, the larynx and trachea are the first organs to show putrefactive changes due to their rich blood supply and presence of resident microflora that facilitate bacterial growth and decomposition.

 

Putrefaction - The disintegration of body tissues after death is known as decomposition. The terms decomposition and putrefaction are used as synonyms. Putrefaction usually follows the disappearance of rigor mortis.

 

The characteristic features of putrefaction are –

  1. Changes in the color of the tissues,
  2. The evolution of gases in the tissues, and
  3. The liquefaction of tissues.

 

The same changes seen on the surface of the body occur simultaneously in internal organs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Order of appearance of putrefaction from earliest to last is -

 

Larynx, Trachea > Stomach, Intestine > Spleen, Liver > Brain, Lungs > Heart > Kidney, Bladder > Uterus/Prostate > Skin, Muscle, Tendon > Bone.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 168

questions.text: A group of forensic medicine junior residents are reviewing a case where a body was found in an advanced state of decomposition. The Senior resident uses this opportunity to teach about Casper's dictum, which can aid in postmortem interval estimations. The JRs are asked which aspect of forensic medicine Casper’s dictum is most helpful. What is the primary use of Casper's dictum?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Estimation of time since death

 

Option A:

 

Casper's dictum is an empirical rule that suggests that a body decomposes twice as fast in air as it does in water and eight times as fast as it does in soil. This principle is primarily used to estimate the time since death, especially in cases where the body is found in different environments, and decomposition has begun.

 

It is a guideline that can help forensic experts to make more accurate determinations about how long a person has been deceased based on the observed level of decomposition.

 

An uncoffined buried body is reduced to a skeleton within 1 to 2 years in India.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. While the state of a body's decomposition might provide some clues about the cause of death, Casper's dictum is not specifically used for this purpose.

 

Option C. The manner of death (natural, accidental, suicidal, or homicidal) is determined by the circumstances surrounding the death, not by the rate of decomposition.

 

Option D. Casper's dictum relates to the rate of decomposition in different environments, not specifically to the process of tissue liquefaction, which is a part of the decomposition process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Casper's dictum is a rule used to estimate the time since death by comparing the rates of decomposition in air, water, and soil. According to this principle, a body decomposes in air twice as fast as it does in water, and eight times as fast as it does when buried in soil.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 170

choices.text: Adipocere formation is unhelpful in establishing the identity of the deceased.
A warm and humid environment is necessary for the development of adipocere.
Clostridium perfringens bacteria are commonly involved in the development of adipocere.
Fetuses under seven months of gestation do not exhibit adipocere formation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male was found deceased in his bathtub filled with water in an apartment with no air conditioning during a heatwave. The body was in the water for an estimated two weeks. During the autopsy, the forensic pathologist noted the presence of a waxy substance on the body. The pathologist is discussing the formation of adipocere with medical residents and mentions several facts about its development. Which of the following statements about adipocere is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adipocere formation is unhelpful in establishing the identity of the deceased.

 

Explanation:

 

This statement is NOT true. Adipocere can actually preserve certain features of the deceased, such as facial characteristics and sometimes even fingerprints, which can be helpful in establishing identity. Adipocere is a postmortem change that can protect the body from further decomposition, sometimes preserving features for extended periods.

 

Adipocere (Saponification/Grave Wax)

 

  • It is a modification of putrefaction in which pre-existing fatty tissues of body undergo hydrolysis and hydrogenation, followed by combination with calcium and ammonium ions to produce into a substance called adipocere.

  • It is seen most commonly in bodies immersed in water or in damp, warm environment (Option B)

  • Intrinsic lipase and Cl. Perfringens is mainly responsible for adipocere formation. (option C)

  • Favorable conditions for adipocere formation

    • Warm environment

    • Fog, misty and humid climate

    • Fatty female and newborn

    • More deep graves

    • Alkaline pH

    • Lead and Zn Coffins

    • The Usual sites are face, buttock, breast, and abdomen.

  • In India it begins within 4 to 5 days.

  • Fetus under 7 months of gestation does not show adipocere. (option D)

  • Medicolegal Significance:

    • Climate

    • Time since death estimation.

    • Person identification and injury identification is easy as body structures are preserved after adipocere

 

Educational Objective:

 

Person identification and injury identification is easy as body structures are preserved after adipocere. It is seen most commonly in bodies immersed in water or in damp, warm environments. Intrinsic lipase and Cl. Perfringens is mainly responsible for adipocere formation. Fetus under 7 months of gestation does not show adipocere.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 171

questions.text: A forensic science student is examining a case study where a body exhibited an unusual glow during the postmortem examination. The instructor explains that this phenomenon, known as postmortem luminescence, can be caused by specific types of bacteria. Which bacteria are known to produce Postmortem Luminescence?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Photobacterium fischeri
 

Option A:

 

Postmortem luminescence is usually due to contamination by bacteria, e.g., Photobacterium fischeri (marine bacteria), and the light comes from them and not from putrefying material.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Armillaria mellea, also known as honey fungus, is a bioluminescent fungus. This can also contribute to luminescent phenomena, including decomposing organic material. But this is not the answer as the question is asking about "bacteria"

 

Option C. Clostridium welchii (also known as Clostridium perfringens) does not produce luminescence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postmortem luminescence is usually due to contamination by bacteria, e.g., Photobacterium fischeri and Luminescent fungi, Armillaria mellea, is another source of light. The question is specifically asking about "bacteria".

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 167

questions.text: In a forensic pathology lecture, the topic of adipocere formation is being discussed. The lecturer poses a question about which organs can or cannot undergo adipocere change. Which organ is least likely to show any adipocere change?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brain

 

Option A:

 

Adipocere, also known as grave wax, is a postmortem change that typically involves the transformation of fat into a waxy substance. Since the brain does not have significant fat stores and consists mainly of neural tissue, it is least likely to undergo adipocere change compared to other organs that have higher fat content.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The lungs may develop adipocere in their fatty tissues, although it is less common due to their high-water content and airy structure.

 

Option C. The liver can develop adipocere, especially considering its large amount of intracellular fat.

 

Option D. While kidneys have less fat compared to some other organs, they still contain enough that they could potentially undergo adipocere formation under the right conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adipocere change is less likely to occur in the brain due to its low-fat content compared to other organs. Favorable conditions for adipocere formations are - Warm environment, Fog, misty and humid climate, Fatty female and newborn, more deep graves, Alkaline pH, Lead and Zn Coffins. The Usual sites are face, buttock, breast, and abdomen.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 171

questions.text: A forensic expert is conducting a session in workshop with medical students on the topic of postmortem changes. The expert presents a scenario where a body has been found in a relatively preserved state several days postmortem. The body initially exhibited rigor mortis, which has since passed, and now the muscles are again relaxed. The expert asks the students to determine which postmortem muscle changes are associated with an alkaline reaction. Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both A and C

 

Cadaveric spasm represents a condition where muscles can instantaneously stiffen now of death, possibly due to a sudden surge in pH. Secondary relaxation refers to the period following rigor mortis, where the muscles once again become flaccid. During this phase, the breakdown of body tissues may lead to an alkaline environment as decomposition progresses. This alkaline reaction contrasts with the initial acidic environment seen during rigor mortis due to the accumulation of lactic acid.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rigor mortis is characterized by an initial acidic reaction due to lactic acid buildup, but as decomposition progresses, the environment can become alkaline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediately after death, the muscles undergo primary relaxation (Somatic Death), which is followed by stiffening of muscles known as rigor mortis. With the onset of putrefaction, rigor mortis passes off, and secondary relaxation (Flaccidity) occurs. Secondary relaxation occurs at around 36 hours after death due to the breakdown of the contracted muscles due to decomposition.

 

Rigor mortis is the postmortem stiffening/ rigidity of the body. It results from a decrease in levels of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) beyond critical levels.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 164

questions.text: During a hospital rotation in forensic medicine, a resident is tasked with explaining the physiological changes that occur after death. They discuss hypostasis and are asked about the specific layer of the skin where it is most prominently developed. In which layer of the skin does hypostasis, the settling of blood after death, predominantly develop?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dermis

 

Option B:

 

  • Hypostasis refers to the pooling of blood in the dependent parts of the body after death, causing a purplish-red discoloration known as livor mortis.
  • This phenomenon predominantly occurs in the dermis, where the small blood vessels that have ceased to circulate blood settle due to gravity.
  • Hypostasis presence or absence is used to determine the approximate time of death.
  • Synonyms are - postmortem staining, subcutaneous hypostasis, livor mortis, cadaveric lividity, suggillations, vibices and darkening of death.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The epidermis does not contain blood vessels where hypostasis could develop.

 

Option C.The hypodermis/ subcutaneous layer contains larger blood vessels and fat tissue; while it may be involved hypostasis is more pronounced in the dermis.

 

Option D. Just below the skin - too vague term.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PM Hypostasis is the bluish-purple or purplish red (due to deoxyhaemoglobin) discoloration, which appears under the skin in the most superficial layers of the dermis (rete mucosum) of the dependent parts of the body after death, due to capillo-venous distention. It is caused by the stoppage of circulation, the stagnation of blood in blood vessels, and its tendency to sink by force of gravity.

 

Ref:  Reddy 33/e. Pg 155

choices.text: A warm and dry atmosphere is needed.
The body has a rancid butter smell
Identification of the body is possible

questions.text: During a forensic medicine viva, a medical student is shown a photograph. The examiner asked the student to read & understand the options carefully and identify the false statement regarding the appearance of the body in the photo. Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The body has a rancid butter smell.

 

Option B:

 

This statement is false regarding mummification. Mummification typically results in a body drying out, not decomposing, which means it would not produce a rancid butter smell — a description more associated with adipocere formation. Instead, mummification would likely lead too little to no odor due to dehydration and preservation of the tissues.

 

Some important Pointers related to Mummification -

 

  • Drying and shriveling of dead body due to evaporation of water but the natural appearance and features of the body are preserved.
  • It is odorless.
  • Occur when the environmental condition is hot and dry, free circulation of air, absence of moisture.
  • Chronic antimony and arsenic poisoning favor the process of mummification.
  • Entire body loses up to 60 to 70% of total body weight
  • Three months to one year is required for mummification.
  • Medicolegal significance:
    • Climate
    • Time since death estimation.
    • Person identification and injury identification is easy as body structure are preserved after mummification."

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Mummification is indeed facilitated by a warm and dry atmosphere, which aids in the dehydration of the body.

 

Option C: Arsenic is a preservative and can favor the mummification process by inhibiting decomposition.

 

Option D: Mummification can preserve features that make identification of the body possible, such as facial characteristics or tattoos.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warm and dry environment favors the mummification process, and mummification can allow for the preservation of identifiable features. The presence of a rancid butter smell is not characteristic of mummification but rather of adipocere formation.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 172-173

choices.text: Along the lesser curvature to minimize disruption of contents.
Along the greater curvature for a comprehensive examination.
Through the anterior midline to approach centrally.
Through the posterior midline as an alternative method.

questions.text: First year junior resident in forensic medicine is being instructed on proper autopsy techniques. The senior resident is conducting the autopsy and demonstrating the examination of the gastrointestinal tract and asks the resident about the correct incision site for inspecting the stomach. Which of the following is the preferred incision site to open the stomach during an autopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Along the greater curvature for a comprehensive examination.

 

Explanation:

 

The standard practice for opening the stomach during an autopsy is along the greater curvature. This method provides the most comprehensive view of the stomach lining and contents while maintaining the integrity of the organ.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The proper technique for examining the stomach, which involves an incision along the greater curvature to allow for a detailed and systematic evaluation.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 509

choices.text: The body must be handed over to the investigating police officer after the postmortem examination for further legal proceedings.
Consent of the deceased's relatives is necessary for conducting the postmortem examination.
The investigating police officer is required to be present inside the autopsy room to observe the proceedings.
Biological samples collected during the autopsy must be given to the investigating officer in an unsealed condition for further forensic analysis.

questions.text: A group of interns are attending a medico-legal autopsy. The supervising resident is briefing the students on the legalities and protocols. Which of the following statements accurately reflects the protocol for a medico-legal autopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The body must be handed over to the investigating police officer after the postmortem examination for further legal proceedings.
 

Option A:

 

While the body is indeed handed over to the police (Investigation Officer) after examination, it is done so with appropriate documentation and chain-of-custody maintenance, which is crucial in medico-legal cases.

 

Rules of Autopsy:

 

  • Starts only when get an official order from the police/magistrate.
  • Conducted in a mortuary.
  • Examination should be conducted in daylight as far as possible for better appreciation of jaundice, color change of bruises etc. nowadays night autopsies are conducted at different centers of India.
  • No unauthorized person should be present at autopsy.
  • Both positive and important negative findings should be noted during examination.
  • After PM (Postmortem) examination, the body should be handed over to the investigating officer, not relatives.
  • PM report should not be issued to the third party.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Incorrect. In India, consent from relatives is not required for medico-legal autopsies as these are typically mandated by legal authorities when the cause of death is unknown, suspicious, or unnatural.

 

Option C. Incorrect. The investigating police officer is required to be present inside the autopsy room to observe the proceedings. No unauthorized person should be present at autopsy.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Samples collected during a medico-legal autopsy are carefully sealed and labeled to preserve the chain of custody and prevent contamination or tampering.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objectives of autopsy

 

  • To ascertain cause of death, time since death, manner of death
  • To find out how the injuries have occurred and its correlation with the weapon.
  • To collect physical evidence in order to identify the criminals or prove the offense.

 

Ref:Reddy 33/e. Pg 103-104

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation and hypertension was admitted to the hospital after being found unconscious at home. On examination, he was noted to have a focal neurological deficit. A CT scan of the head revealed an area consistent with an acute infarct. The patient deteriorated rapidly and was pronounced dead. At autopsy, the pathologist discovered a thrombus in the cerebral artery with a distinct coralline appearance. This finding is characteristic of which type of thrombus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antemortem thrombus

 

Option A:

 

  • Coralline platelet thrombus is indicative of an antemortem thrombus.
  • This is because the structure of the thrombus suggests that it was formed prior to death when the circulatory system was still active.
  • Antemortem blood clots thrombi: They are dark red, firm but friable, dry, pale, granular, adherent to vessel wall and on section show alternate layers of platelets and fibrin (coralline platelet thrombus).
  • Dark lines are composed of red cells and a network of fine white lines of fibrin.
  • The older thrombus is greyish-red and varies in color from place to place.
  • When lung is sliced, emboli slightly project above the surface.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Postmortem thrombus typically lacks the layered structure of an antemortem thrombus, as it forms after the heart has stopped beating and blood flow has ceased.

 

The postmortem thrombus is dark-red, glistening, soft, jelly-like, and very friable. When pulled out of the vessels it forms a cast of the branches. When the lung is sliced, clot does not pour out of cut small vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coralline platelet thrombus is a feature of antemortem thrombus, which helps in differentiating it from postmortem clots during autopsy findings.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 112

questions.text: During a Forensic Lab rotation, a medical student is presented with a heart showing signs of atrophy and a brown discoloration of the myocardium. The supervising resident discusses the changes with the student and inquires about the possible underlying condition that could result in such a presentation. Brown atrophy of the heart is most commonly associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Starvation

 

Option D:

 

Brown atrophy of the heart is a condition that typically occurs in the context of chronic wasting diseases, such as starvation, where there is a loss of cardiac muscle mass and a brown discoloration due to the accumulation of lipofuscin pigment within the myocardium. It is often seen in elderly patients as a part of the aging process as well.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Myocardial Infarction leads to coagulative necrosis of the myocardial tissue, not brown atrophy.

 

Option B. Pericarditis does not directly cause brown atrophy of the heart muscle itself.

 

Option C. Chronic Arsenic Poisoning - Subendocardial petechial hemorrhage of ventricles are common, but it is not associated with brown atrophy of the heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brown atrophy of the heart is a feature of chronic conditions such as starvation or cachexia, characterized by a brown discoloration due to lipofuscin pigment and a reduction in cardiac muscle mass.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 336

questions.text: A forensic medicine resident is asked about the timeline of postmortem changes in a cadaver. Specifically, Faculty is inquiring about when hairs become loose and easily pluckable following death. In this context, hairs are typically loose and easily pluckable after how many hours of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 72 hours

 

Explanation:

 

Post-Mortem Hair Loosening, known as postmortem hair slip, usually begins around 72 hours after death as part of the decomposition process. This can vary depending on environmental conditions and the individual's hair type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Timing of postmortem changes, particularly the loosening of hair, which usually occurs approximately after 3 days of death and can be used as a rough indicator in estimating the time since death in forensic cases.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 167

choices.text: Presence of Hematoma in the surrounding Soft Tissue with Signs of Inflammation

questions.text: During a forensic rotation, a medical intern examines a case involving a 55-year-old male who was found deceased at the bottom of a staircase. The autopsy report indicates a spinal fracture, but there is no significant external trauma or evidence of hematoma or soft tissue inflammation in the neck region.  Based on these findings, which of the following statements is true about the nature of the spinal injury, traditionally referred to as Undertaker's fracture in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fracture of C6-C7 vertebrae.

 

Option C:

 

Undertaker's fracture is a subluxation of the lower cervical spine due to tearing of the intervertebral disc at about C6-C7. This is one of the artefacts due to the rough Handling of the Body.

 

Other Artefacts due to the Handling of the Body are –

 

  1. Fractures of the ribs or the bones of extremities, or of cervical spine, especially if there is severe osteoporosis. They are commonly produced during attempts to straighten the limbs contracted due to rigor mortis. Bleeding is usually absent in such postmortem fractures.
  2. Contusion of the occipital region may be caused, if the head of corpse is allowed to fall on a hard surface during handling.
  3. Fresh abrasions may be produced due to dragging of the body which were originally free from them, during the transfer of the body from the scene of crime.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. It is a Postmortem fracture that occurred due to rough handling of the body.

 

Option B. Incorrect. Postmortem fracture occurred due to rough handling of the body.

 

Option D. Incorrect, as there was no significant external trauma or evidence of hematoma or soft tissue inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Undertaker's fracture is a subluxation of the lower cervical spine due to tearing of the intervertebral disc at about C6-C7.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/E. Pg 469

questions.text: In a forensic toxicology lab, a technician is preparing to preserve organ tissue samples for toxicological analysis. The tissue needs to be stored in a way that prevents enzymatic degradation and bacterial growth without altering any potential toxic substances. Which of the following is the most common preservative for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Saturated solution of common salt

 

Option A:

 

  • The most used preservative for viscera is saturated solution of common salt. It is easily available, cheap, and effective preservative.

  • Saturated Sodium chloride solution is used as preservative except in cases of poisoning from corrosive acids, alkalis, corrosive sublimate, and aconite.

 

Some important Pointers –

 

  • 10 mg./ml of sodium or potassium fluoride (prevents glycolysis, inhibits enzyme enolase, and inhibits bacterial growth) and 3 mg oxalate (anti-coagulant) should be used for preserving blood. Fluoride should also be added to urine, CSF, and vitreous humor if alcohol estimation is required, and also to samples for analysis for cocaine, cyanide, and CO.

  • In poisoning by oxalic acid, ethylene glycol, fluoride and CO, 30 mg sodium citrate should be added to 10 ml of blood as preservative.

  • Preservative is not necessary if - 

    • Viscera can be analyzed within 24 hours,

    • If sample can be kept in a refrigerator or ice box,

    • Bone, hair, nails,

    • Lung for detecting inhaled poisons.

  • The viscera should not be preserved in formaldehyde because extraction of poison, especially non-volatile organic compounds become difficult.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rectified spirit (ethanol) is the ideal preservative for viscera in toxicological analysis because it inhibits enzymatic and bacterial activity without interfering significantly with the chemical composition of potential toxins. This property is crucial for accurate toxicological analysis. While rectified spirit is most ideal, but most commonly used is saturated solution of common salt as it is easily available.

 

Rectified spirit NOT used in cases of suspected poisoning by (a) alcohol, kerosene, (b) chloroform, ether, (c) chloral hydrate, (d) formic acid, (e) formaldehyde, acetic acid, (f) phenol, (g) phosphorus, and (h) paraldehyde, because the organic acids and paraldehyde are soluble in alcohol and the phosphorescence of phosphorus is diminished by potassium alcohol.

 

Option C. Formalin is excellent for tissue preservation in histopathology but can interfere with toxicological analysis by altering the chemical structure of certain substances.

 

Option D. Methanol is not typically used for preserving tissues due to its potential to interfere with the analysis of various substances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Saturated solution of common salt - most commonly used preservative for viscera

  • Rectified spirit is the ideal preservative for viscera in toxicological analysis

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 124-125

questions.text: A medical student is observing an autopsy. The Senior Resident explains the procedure for systematically examining and removing the internal organs. Which method is most commonly used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Virchow

 

Option A:

 

The Virchow method is the most commonly used technique for removing viscera during an autopsy. It involves the sequential removal of individual organs for detailed examination, allowing for a thorough assessment of each organ.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rokitansky's method involves the en masse removal of organs in a connected block, which is less commonly used due to the difficulty in detailed examination. Done in patient with highly transmissible disease, e.g. HIV, HBV. This method also sued in case of infant autopsy and radiation hazards.

 

Option C. Gohn's method is not a standard or widely recognized method for organ removal in autopsy practice. As organ block, e.g. thoracic block means heart and lungs removed at a time. Similarly abdominal block, urogenital block etc.

 

Option D. Let tulle’s method is less commonly used and involves a variation of the en masse technique. Cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs at a time. This is the best technique for preserving the vascular supply and anatomical relationship between the organs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Virchow method is the most commonly used technique for removing viscera during an autopsy due to its systematic approach in examining individual organs.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 109

questions.text: During a training session in forensic medicine, a resident learns about the importance of analyzing vitreous humor in determining the postmortem interval. Which constituent of vitreous humor is most helpful in accurately estimating the postmortem interval?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) K

 

Option B:

 

  • Potassium (K) levels in the vitreous humor are particularly useful in estimating the postmortem interval.
  • The potassium concentration at the time of death is 5 to 8 mmol/l. The rise of potassium concentration per hour is 0.17 to 0.238 mmol per hour. The reason for varying range may be due to electrolyte imbalances at the time of death. The variation between the two eyes may be up to 10%
  • There is a linear relationship between vitreous potassium concentration and time elapsed after death up to 120 hours. The 95% limits of confidence are ±20 hours up to 100 hours.
  • The rise is mainly due to diffusion from the retina into the center of the globe. Temperature, chillness, and urea retention affect the range.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sodium levels change postmortem but are not as reliable as potassium for estimating time since death. sodium decreases by about 0.9 mmol/l/h after death.

 

Option C.  Chlorides level decrease by rate of less than 1 mmol/l/h in postmortem period but are not as useful as potassium levels for this purpose.

 

Option D. The vitreous glucose usually falls after death and can reach zero within a few hours. A vitreous glucose of more than 11.1 mmol/l indicates diabetes, and less than 1.4 mmol/1 of hypoglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A steady rise in the potassium values occur in the vitreous humour after death up to 100 hours.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 154

questions.text: A Forensic Expert is examining a body that has recovered from an indoor setting with controlled environmental conditions. What is the minimum time required to develop the change as shown in picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Three weeks.

 

Explanation:

 

Time Required for Adipocere Formation: The rate is extremely variable.

 

  • In temperate countries, the shortest time for its formation is about three weeks in summer, when it occurs to a certain extent.

  • Stiffening, hardening and swelling of the fat occur over a period of months. In most cases, the change is partial and irregular, but rarely the whole body may be affected.

  • Complete conversion in an adult limb requires at least three to six months.

  • In India, it has been observed to begin within 4 to 5 days.

  • Adipocere may persist for years or decades.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In temperate countries, the shortest time for the adipocere formation is about three weeks, but in India, it has been observed to begin within 4 to 5 days. Complete conversion in an adult limb requires at least three to six months.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 171

questions.text: While attending a workshop on forensic preservation techniques, a medical student learns about the composition of various embalming solutions used in mortuaries. The instructor emphasizes one particular component crucial for inhibiting autolysis and putrefaction in cadavers stored for autopsy or educational purposes. Which of the following substances is primarily responsible for this preservative effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formalin.

 

Explanation:

 

Formalin, a solution of formaldehyde in water, is a commonly used preservative in embalming fluids due to its excellent preservation properties and ability to inactivate bacteria and viruses.

 

The typical embalming fluid contains –

 

 

Embalming –

 

  • Is the treatment of the dead body with antiseptics and preservatives to prevent putrefaction and preserve the body. By this process proteins are coagulated, tissues are fixed, organs are bleached and hardened and blood is converted into a brownish mass.
  • Embalming produces a chemical stiffening similar to rigor mortis, and normal rigor does not develop. Embalming rigidity is permanent.
  • Injection of femoral artery will produce more even distribution of embalming fluid, and drainage from internal jugular vein will give quickest clearing of face. In obese bodies, injection of carotid artery and drainage from internal jugular vein is the best choice.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Methanol is primarily an industrial solvent and is not commonly used as a preservative in embalming fluids due to its toxicity and less effective preservation properties.

 

Option C. Glycerin is used in embalming to help retain body moisture and maintain the deceased's natural appearance, but it does not have significant preservative properties against decomposition.

 

Option D. Sodium citrate may be used to prevent blood clotting in the vascular system of a cadaver, but it does not preserve tissue against decomposition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Embalming preserves and stiffens the body by using chemicals to prevent decay, with fluid distribution best achieved through femoral artery injection and quick facial clearing via internal jugular vein drainage. Formalin as the primary constituent in embalming fluid used for cadaver preservation.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 173

questions.text: A forensic medicine research fellow is attending a seminar on legal medicine, where a discussion on the statutory guidelines for exhumation in India is underway. The fellow learns that the legal authority for exhumation is determined by the necessity for investigation and not constrained by a specific time frame. What does Indian law stipulate as the time frame within which a body can be exhumed for forensic examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No limit.

 

Explanation:

 

In India, there is no specific time limit for ordering the exhumation of a body. The decision can be made based on the merits of each case, regardless of the time that has elapsed since burial.

 

Some important Pointers related to EXHUMATION:

 

  • Exhumation is the legal digging out of an already buried body legally from the grave.
  • There is no time limit for exhumation in India.
  • Authorization: The body is exhumed only when there is a written order from the Executive Magistrate (S. 176 CrPC). The body can be exhumed by any government doctor.
  • The body is exhumed under the supervision of a medical officer and Magistrate in the presence of a police officer.
  • In cases of suspected mineral poisoning, samples of the earth (about half kg.) in actual contact with the body and also from above, below and from each side should be collected. All personal effects, clothing, hair, nails. etc., should be picked up for examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, there is no specified time limit for ordering the exhumation of a body for investigation purposes.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 666

questions.text: As a junior resident in the forensic department, you are required to collect a tissue sample from an embalmed cadaver for toxicological analysis. The body has been preserved following standard embalming protocols. To obtain the most reliable toxicological data, from which of the following tissues should the sample be taken?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Skeletal muscle from buttock

 

Option B:

 

The rationale for choosing skeletal muscle from the buttock over other tissue options is based on its lower likelihood of being infiltrated by embalming fluids. Since embalming fluids can alter drug concentrations and their distribution within the body, skeletal muscle, due to its density and lower blood supply compared to other organs, is less likely to be affected. This makes it a more reliable source for toxicological analysis in an embalmed cadaver.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Abdominal fat is more likely to absorb embalming fluids, which can complicate the detection and quantification of toxic substances.

 

Option C. Femoral bone may contain trace elements of substances, but it is not the best indicator of recent toxic exposure and requires more complex processing.

 

Option D. Brain tissue is highly vascular and thus can be significantly affected by embalming fluids; it also undergoes rapid autolytic changes, which can further complicate toxicological analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In embalmed body the best specimen for toxicological analysis is skeletal muscle from the buttock due to its minimal exposure to embalming fluids and reliable representation of the individual's toxicological profile at the time of death.

 

Ref:Reddy 33/e. Pg 125

questions.text: During your internship in the forensic medicine department, you are involved in the autopsy of an exhumed body. Preparing for a discussion with the senior resident, you study the procedural aspects of exhumations. According to standard forensic practices, when is exhumation most performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Early morning.

 

Explanation:

 

Exhumation is typically performed in the early morning. This timing allows for cooler temperatures which can help preserve the condition of the remains and ensures the process can be conducted in daylight while minimizing the exposure to onlookers and the potential for disruption.

 

Some important Pointers related to EXHUMATION:

 

  • Exhumation is the legal digging out of an already buried body legally from the grave.
  • There is no time limit for exhumation in India.
  • Authorization: The body is exhumed only when there is a written order from the Executive Magistrate (S. 176 CrPC). The body can be exhumed by any government doctor.
  • The body is exhumed under the supervision of a medical officer and Magistrate in the presence of a police officer.
  • In cases of suspected mineral poisoning, samples of the earth (about half kg.) in actual contact with the body and also from above, below and from each side should be collected. All personal effects, clothing, hair, nails. etc., should be picked up for examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exhumations are commonly carried out in the early morning to preserve the integrity of the remains and maintain privacy during the procedure.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 666

questions.text: While attending a practical session on autopsy techniques in forensic, you observed various incision methods employed by the Professor. These incisions are critical for facilitating a comprehensive internal examination while considering factors like post-autopsy appearance and ease of closure. Later Professor emphasizes the standard practices in incision patterns and poses a question to test your understanding. Which of the following incision patterns is NOT typically used in standard medico-legal autopsies?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Modified I-shaped.

 

Option C:

 

Incision patterns are NOT typically used in standard medico-legal autopsies is Modified I shaped.

 

Explanation:

 

SKIN INCISIONS: Primary incisions are of three types –

 

Option A. The "I"-shaped incision, extending from the chin straight down to the symphysis pubis, passing either to the left or right of the umbilicus. The umbilicus is avoided because the dense fibrous tissue is difficult to penetrate with a needle when the body is stitched after autopsy.

 

Option B. "Y"-shaped incision begins at a point close to the acromial process. It extends down below the breast and across to the xiphoid process. A similar incision is then made on the opposite side of the body. From the xiphoid process, the incision is carried downwards to the symphysis pubis.

 

Option D. Modified "Y"-shaped incision: An incision is made in midline from suprasternal notch to symphysis pubis. The incision extends from suprasternal notch over the clavicle to its center on both sides and then passes upwards over the neck behind the ear.

 

 

The incision must be adopted according to the special condition of the case, e.g., in stab wounds of the chest or abdomen, the usual incision may have to be altered to avoid such wounds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary skin incisions are of three types - I, Y, and modified Y

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 107

questions.text: During a lecture, the topic of Indian Penal Code (IPC) sections relevant to forensic is discussed. You learned about various IPC sections that are commonly encountered in forensic practice. One of the sections discussed is IPC 201. Based on your understanding, which of the following offenses is addressed by IPC 201?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Punishment for embalming before autopsy.

 

Option A:

 

IPC 201 deals with the destruction of evidence, this includes actions such as embalming a body before an autopsy is conducted. Embalming before autopsy can potentially destroy vital evidence that could determine the cause of death or other forensic details, thereby hindering a legal investigation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Perjury - Giving willful false or fabricate dividend under oath (Definition IPC 191) ; Punishment is imprisonment up to 7 years (IPC 193)
 

Option C. Voluntarily causing grievous hurt - Grievous hurt defines under S 320 IPC and 325 IPC describes Punishment for Voluntarily Causing Grievous Hurt (imprisonment which may extend for 7 years with or without fine.)

 

Option D. Kidnapping - Offence of kidnapping comprised under Section 359-374 IPC. Abduction is defined under Section 362 of IPC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

S. 201, I.P.C.: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offenders (imprisonment up to ten years).

 

Ref:Reddy 33/e. Pg 55

questions.text: Post-mortem lividity, also known as livor mortis, is a key sign that can help in determining the position of the body at the time of death. However, its development can be influenced by environmental factors. In which of the following drowning scenarios is post-mortem lividity least likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Drowning in fast flowing river.

 

Option D:

 

Post-mortem lividity is less likely to develop or be observable in bodies that drown in fast flowing rivers. The constant movement and turbulence in a fast-flowing river can disrupt the settling of blood in the dependent parts of the body, which is essential for the formation of post-mortem lividity. This continuous motion can either prevent the pooling of blood or cause any lividity that forms to be less distinct.

 

Explanation: -

 

Option A. Drowning in a well: Post-mortem lividity can develop, as the body is likely to remain stationary, allowing blood to pool in the dependent parts.

 

Option B. Post-mortem submersion: Lividity can still develop, especially if the body was on land for a period before being submerged. The water may alter its appearance but does not prevent its formation.

 

Option C. Drowning in a swimming pool: Similar to drowning in a well, the body is relatively stationary, allowing for the development of post-mortem lividity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-mortem lividity is less likely to develop or be noticeable in drowning cases involving fast flowing rivers due to the disruption of blood settling caused by the movement of water.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 365-366

questions.text: During a viva, you have to examine the below mentioned photograph of a crime scene. The image displays a distinct post-mortem phenomenon on the body. Based on the visual characteristics, what is the most likely post-mortem change depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Suggillation.

 

Option C:

 

Suggilation, also known as livor mortis or post-mortem lividity, refers to the purple or dark bluish discoloration of the skin in dependent areas of the body after death. It is caused by the pooling of blood in the lower parts of the body due to gravity, and it is typically visible in cases where the body has remained in one position for an extended period after death.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Post-mortem rigidity, or rigor mortis, refers to the stiffening of the body's muscles after death but does not cause discoloration.

 

Option B. Kevorkian sign - Earliest sign after death. Fragmentation or segmentation (tuking or shunting) of the blood columns in the retinal vessels appear within minutes after death and persists for about an hour. This occurs all over the body due to loss of blood pressure, but it can be seen only in retina by ophthalmoscope. The retina is pale for the first two hours. At about six hours, the disk outline is hazy and becomes blurred in 7 to 10 hours. These changes are of little practical value.

 

 

Option D. Tache noir - Darkening of the sclera and other tissues of the eye, If the eyelids are open for a few hours after death.

 

The corneal opacity is due to drying and is delayed for about two hours if the lids are closed after death. If the eyelids are open for a few hours after death, a film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera at each side of the iris, with base towards the margin of cornea and apex towards medial or lateral canthus of the eye, which become brown and then black called "tache noir" within 3 to 4 hours, upon which dust settles and the surface becomes wrinkled.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suggilation (post-mortem lividity) as a post-mortem change that manifests as a dark discoloration of the skin in dependent areas of the body due to the pooling of blood.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 153-155

choices.text: The baby had phrenic nerve damage
The baby had not respired prior to death
The baby had respired prior to death
Nothing significant can be inferred from this finding

questions.text: A forensic specialist is performing an autopsy on a newborn baby. During the examination, it is observed that the diaphragm of the baby is situated at a lower level than expected. What inference can be drawn from this finding about the baby's state prior to death?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The baby had respired prior to death

 

 

Option C:

 

While performing an autopsy in a new-born the goal is to know whether the baby is live born or not (i.e., respired/ not). For this the abdomen is opened first and the highest point of the diaphragm is noted by passing a finger. When the baby starts respiring, expanded lungs push the diaphragm down. If the diaphragm is at a lower level, that means the baby has respired. If the diaphragm is at a higher level, that means the baby hasn't respired.

 

The position is also affected by gases of decomposition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Phrenic nerve damage in an infant can lead to an elevation of the diaphragm on the affected side rather than a lowering of the diaphragm. This happens because the diaphragm is primarily controlled by the phrenic nerves, which stimulate the muscle to contract. When one or both phrenic nerves are damaged, the normal contraction of the diaphragm on the affected side becomes compromised. Phrenic nerves can be injured during a traumatic childbirth.

 

Option B. The baby had not respired prior to death: The lower position of the diaphragm act suggests opposite; that the baby had respired.

 

Option D. Nothing significant can be inferred from this finding: This is incorrect because the position of the diaphragm is a valuable indicator in forensic examinations to determine whether respiration occurred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diaphragm positioning emphasizes the significance of respiratory indicators in determining whether a newborn had breathed prior to death, which can be pivotal in medicolegal investigations to establish the circumstances surrounding the newborn's death.

 

Diaphragm Level Before Respiration: 4th - 5th Rib.

 

Diaphragm Level After Respiration: 6th - 7th Rib.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 439
