questions.text: In a dramatic turn of events at a large industrial plant, a worker is found lying motionless near a high-voltage electrical panel. The emergency response team rushes to the scene, where they find no visible injuries, but the worker is unresponsive and without apparent signs of life. Which of the following scenarios is most likely to result in a state of suspended animation, where the victim might appear lifeless but is still alive?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Electrocution

 

 

Option A:

 

Suspended animation is when an organism’s bodily functions, like breathing and heartbeat, are drastically slowed down or paused as seen in electrocution.

 

Suspended animation

 

Suspended animation is a condition in which vital signs of life (heartbeat and respiration) are not detected by routine clinical methods, as the functions are interrupted for some time or are reduced to a minimum.

 

Mechanism: The metabolic rate is greatly reduced so that the requirement of the individual cell for oxygen is satisfied through the dissolved oxygen in body fluids

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Strangulation/ hanging,

 

Option C. Firearm injury and Option D. Burn: suspended animation is not usually seen in these conditions.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suspended animation is found in following conditions:

 

  1. After Anesthesia
  2. Newborn, Barbiturate poisoning
  3. Cholera,Coma, Cerebral Concussion
  4. Drowning
  5. Electrocution
  6. Frozen state (Hypothermia)
  7. Sunstroke, Shock, InSanity
  8. Yoga practitioners

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 152

questions.text: Identify the image shown below and what does it indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Death

 

Option C:

 

  • The blood in retinal vessels appears fragmented or segmented (cattle trucking or shunting) within seconds to minutes after death, this sign is called Kevorkian sign. This is the earliest sign after death.
  • This occurs all over the body due to loss of blood pressure, but it can be seen only in retina by ophthalmoscope. The retina is pale for the first two hours.
  • At about six hours, the disk outline is hazy and becomes blurred in 7 to 10 hours. These changes are of little practical value.

 

Other Postmortem changes in the eye –

 

  1. Loss of corneal and pupillary reflexes: It may be seen in all cases of deep insensibility and therefore is present after death.
  2. Opacity of the cornea: There is opacity and haziness of the cornea due to drying and deposition of dust and debris over it.
     
  3. Tache noire: If the eyelids remain open for 3–4 h after death, there is formation of two yellow triangles on the sclera at each side of the iris, which become brown and then black. This happens because of drying/desiccation, and deposition of cellular debris, mucus and dust on the exposed conjunctiva and the sclera underneath.
     
  4. Loss of intraocular tension: Intraocular tension falls rapidly after death. It becomes zero in 4–8 h from 10–22 mmHg during life. The eyeballs look sunken in the orbit.
     
  5. Vitreous potassium and hypoxanthine: Steady rise in the values are seen after death. The rise is due to the autolysis of the vascular choroids and retinal cells of the eye.

 

Explanation:

 

A. Head injury and B. Eye injury: Incorrect. As explained above Kevorkian sign is seen after death when the blood pressure drops which is not a case in head injury or eye injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postmortem changes in the retina: The blood in retinal vessels appears fragmented or segmented (cattle trucking or shunting) within seconds to minutes after death and persists for about an hour (Kevorkian sign). This occurs all over the body due to loss of blood pressure, but it can be seen only in retina by an ophthalmoscope.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 152

questions.text: During a forensic investigation, the team is examining a body to establish the time of death. One of the key observations made is the stiffening of the muscles. The team is considering whether this stiffening is true rigor mortis or if it could be a phenomenon that simulates rigor mortis. Which of the following could potentially simulate the appearance of rigor mortis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cadaveric spasm

 

Explanation:

 

Conditions Simulating (looking like) Rigor mortis as they cause body stiffening:

 

1) Cadaveric spasm

  • Continuation of muscle contraction after death which were contracted at time of death.
  • Occurs immediately after death.
  • Only Selected muscles involved (Hands)
  • Intensity of muscle contraction is much more as compared to Rigor Mortis
  • Mechanism: Not known

 

2) Heat Stiffening (Pugilistic or Boxer’s attitude)

  • Shortening and stiffening of muscles due to coagulation of muscle proteins at body temp> 65° C
  • Flexion of elbows, knees, and clenching of hand into a fist.
  • Intensity of muscle contraction is more as compared to Rigor Mortis

 

1. Cold Stiffening

  • In freezing temperatures, the tissues become stiff, due to freezing of the body fluids.
  • My body is extremely cold.
  • On movement of joints, crepitus can be felt due to breaking down of frozen synovial fluid.

 

2. Gas Stiffening

  • Stiffening of the body due to putrefactive gases
  • Other signs of Putrefaction will be present.
  • Not so stiff, joints can be easily moved.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Algor mortis - or chill of death is the cooling of the body that normally takes place after death, where the body temperature equilibrates with its environmental temperature. Algor mortis is usually the first sign of death beyond the obvious and is then followed by rigor mortis. There is no stiffening, so incorrect.

 

Option C. Adipocere - It is the formation of an offensive, sweet rancid smelling, soft, whitish, or grayish white, crumbly, waxy, and greasy material (similar to soap) occurring in fatty tissues of a dead body. There is no stiffening, so answer is incorrect. It is a modification of decomposition. In hot and moist environment, it may occur by the end of 1 week. In temperate countries, it starts in 3 weeks and completes in about 3 months.

 

Option D. Livor mortis - Postmortem staining or PM staining is bluish or purplish-red discoloration resulting from gravitational settling of blood in the toneless capillaries and venules of the dependent parts of the dead body. There is no stiffening, so answer is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cadaveric spasm causes stiffening of body muscles; hence it simulates (looks similar to) rigor mortis. It is believed to occur in sudden deaths, particularly those associated with intense emotion or physical activity.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 162

questions.text: Examine the provided image of a liver from an autopsy case. The forensic pathologist notices characteristic changes in the liver's appearance. Based on these findings, which process affecting the liver is most likely represented in this image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Putrefaction

 

Option A:

 

This image shows honeycomb liver which is seen in putrefaction due to presence of gas bubbles within the parenchyma. The empty spaces or small holes are gas bubbles, produced by bacterial action.

 

Foamy Liver (Honeycomb liver): Anything in which gas bubbles are produced appears like Honeycomb. Apart from Foamy liver, other conditions of Honeycomb appearance are seen in:

 

  • Heat hematoma.
  • Electrocution marks on Histology.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Adipocere: is formation of an offensive, smelling, soft, grayish white, waxy, and greasy material occurring in fatty tissues of a dead body. The below image shows Adipocere.

 

 

Option C. Mummification: It occurs in the absence of moisture in the air. Body is shrunken and contracted, dry, brittle, leathery and rusty brown in color. Below image is of Mummified body.

 

 

Option D. Dry drowning: is a type of atypical drowning. In this water does not enter the lungs due to laryngeal spasm induced by small amounts of water entering the larynx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Putrefaction timelines in summer:

 

  • 12 hrs: Greenish Discoloration (GD) starts becoming visible in right iliac fossa.
  • 12- 24 hrs.: Gas production starts, some spread of greenish discoloration (GD)
  • 24-48 hours: GD over whole-body, Post-mortem Purge, foamy liver, Marbling
  • 48-72 hours: Brownish Black, Prolapse (rectum and uterus), Gas stiffening, nail, and hair loose, face swollen.
  • 72 -120 hrs.: Teeth loose, skull sutures separate, and brain matter comes out, skin comes out as in glove and stocking pattern, heavy maggot infestation leading to multiple holes.
  • 5-10 days: Liquefaction of most organs.
  • Skeletonization (only bones and teeth remain): 1 month.
  • Bones decompose: 10 years.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 168

choices.text: To determine times since death
To determine cause of death
To determine position of the body

questions.text: A forensic expert is presented with a close-up image of an eye from a deceased individual during an autopsy. Notable changes in the eye's appearance may hold significant medicolegal importance. Based on the specific findings observed in the eye, what is the primary medicolegal significance of this ocular finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) To determine time since death

 

Explanation:

 

The picture shows triangular discoloration on sclera on both the sides, this is characteristic of Tache noir. It starts forming a few hours after death due to corneal drying. Its progression can be used to estimate the time since death.

 

The corneal opacity is due to drying and is delayed for about two hours if the lids are closed after death. If the eyelids are open for a few hours after death, a film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera at each side of the iris, with base towards the margin of cornea and apex towards medial or lateral canthus of the eye, which become brown and then black called "tache noir" within 3 to 4 hours, upon which dust settles and the surface becomes wrinkled

 

Other 3 options:

 

Tache noire is not affected by the cause of death, poisoning, or the position of the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tache noir

 

  • Tache noire is the triangle shaped discoloration noted in sclera.
  • In exposed sclera, a film of cell-debris, mucus and dust settles on each side of the cornea
  • Appears reddish-brown initially and then almost Black
  • Time since death can be determined from tache noire- (it appears in 3-4 Hours)

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 153

questions.text: A Forensic Expert is teaching medical students about the process of decomposition and the sequence in which organs undergo putrefaction. He presents a case study where the order of putrefaction is to be determined. Based on the typical progression of putrefaction in human organs, what is the correct sequence?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brain, Heart, Uterus

 

 

Explanation:

 

Putrefaction - is a process by which complex organic body tissue breaks down into simpler inorganic compounds or elements due to the action of saprophytic microorganisms or due to autolysis. Putrefaction usually follows the disappearance of rigor mortis.

 

The characteristic features of putrefaction are:

  1. Changes in the color of the tissues,
  2. The evolution of gases in the tissues, and
  3. The liquefaction of tissues.

 

The same changes seen on the surface of the body occur simultaneously in internal organs.

 

The order of organ putrefaction (early to late) is as follows:

  1. Larynx and trachea
  2. Liver and lungs
  3. Brain
  4. Heart
  5. Kidney
  6. Prostate and non-gravid uterus
  7. Skin, muscle, tendons
  8. Bones and teeth

 

The prostate and non-gravid uterus are organs which putrefy very late. The gravid uterus putrefies earlier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mnemonic for order of Putrefaction: LBHK

 

L for larynx, liver, lungs, B for brain, H for Heart, K for Kidney

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 168

choices.text: In hands and feet in a glove and stocking pattern
On the dorsal aspect of the body, except back of chest and buttocks
Over face, neck, front of upper part of chest, upper and lower limbs.

questions.text: In a rural area, a villager discovers a corpse floating in a pond and promptly contacts the authorities. The body is retrieved and sent for forensic examination to determine various postmortem findings, including the pattern of postmortem staining. Given the body's position in the water, where would the forensic examiner most likely observe postmortem staining?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Over face, neck, front of upper part of chest, upper and lower limbs.

 

 

Option D:

 

Postmortem hypostasis occurs in dependent parts. In drowning, the body floats with face down, buttocks up, legs and arms hanging down in front of the body as shown below:

 

 

Hence, in drowning postmortem staining occurs over face, neck, front of upper part of chest, upper and lower limbs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Only in lower limbs is incorrect as explained above

 

Option B. In hands and feet in a glove and stocking pattern. This occurs in hanging as hands and feet become dependent parts in a suspended body. The staining develops in the lower region of lower limbs and upper limbs (hands/forearms) — glove and stocking PM staining.

 

Option C. On the dorsal aspect of the body, except back of chest and buttocks: This will be seen if the body is lying in supine position. In this position the staining will be absent on the back of chest and buttocks as these are pressure points.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PM Hypostasis is the bluish-purple or purplish red (due to deoxyhemoglobin) discoloration, which appears under the skin in the most superficial layers of the dermis (rete mucosum) of the dependent parts of the body after death, due to capillo-venous distention. It is caused by the stoppage of circulation, the stagnation of blood in blood vessels, and its tendency to sink by force of gravity.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 155

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is conducting an autopsy and observing a clot with a distinctive layered appearance, resembling chicken fat, within the blood vessels of the deceased. This finding is characteristic and indicative of a specific type of thrombus. What type of thrombus is associated with a 'chicken fat' appearance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Postmortem thrombus

 

Option B:

 

The 'chicken fat' appearance is typical of a postmortem thrombus, which is also known as a postmortem clot. These clots can form after the cessation of blood circulation and are often found during autopsies. They have a gelatinous and layered structure, which can be easily distinguished from antemortem thrombi that are firmer and attached to the vessel walls. Antemortem thrombi is formed due to pathophysiological processes while the person is still alive and typically indicates a thrombotic event such as a heart attack or stroke.

 

Two types of Postmortem thrombus:

 

  • Red currant jelly: Occurs if the blood clots rapidly. RBCs do not have time to settle down hence RBCs are distributed in whole clot and hence the clot is uniformly dark red
  • Chicken fat: Occurs if the clotting is gradual. RBCs settle down and two different layers are seen:
    • Upper layer: A pale layer of serum and fibrin
    • Lower layer: Red (like red current layer)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Antemortem thrombus firmly adheres to the lining endothelium, with a pale, granular and transversely ridged surface because of alternating layers of platelets and fibrin.

 

Option C. Gunshot injury - Gunshot wounds are typically characterized by tissue damage, bullet paths, stippling, and soot deposition depending on the range and caliber of the weapon used. Does not lead to thrombus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Appearances of thrombus:

 

 

Ref: Textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology, Anil Agrawal, 2016, page 101

questions.text: A Forensic Expert is teaching medical students about the processes that occur to a body submerged in water. The students are asked to consider why a body that was initially submerged would eventually float to the surface. What is the primary reason for the floatation of a body in water?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of gases

 

 

Option B:

 

Floatation of the body in water:

 

  • Floatation of the body in water occurs due to production of putrefactive gases in the body.
  • The specific gravity of a cadaver is slightly greater than that of water and therefore the body will tend to sink unless sufficient gases are produced to make it buoyant.
  • In India, a submerged body may usually come to the surface by 24 hours in summer and 2–3 days in winter.

 

Factors Influencing Floatation:

 

  1. Decomposition: Early decomposition causes early floatation of the dead body, because accumulation of gas in the tissue increases the buoyancy of the body.
  2. Salinity of water: Floatation occurs early in salty water due to higher specific gravity.
  3. Stagnant water: Promotes early floatation by way of causing early decomposition.
  4. Clothing: It causes early floatation, as it is lighter than water due to air bubbles in between the spaces of the fabrics.
  5. Age: Bodies of mature newly born float earlier than stillborn or immature ones.
  6. Sex: Female bodies are lighter, because of more fat content, so female bodies float early.
  7. Season: Floatation is early in summer than in winter, warm temperature being favorable for decomposition.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Flesh being eaten by fishes: While this can alter the body's mass, it does not contribute significantly to buoyancy.

 

Option C. Water logging of body: Water logging would actually make the body heavier and not aid in floatation.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because the presence of gases is the primary cause, while the other factors listed do not significantly contribute to the floatation of a body.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The factors like age, sex, clothing, condition of the body, season of the year and nature of water (whether polluted or otherwise, stagnant or running, sea water or ordinary, etc.) all influence the period of floatation owing to playing their role upon the rate of putrefying process and consequent production of gases.

 

Ref: Textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology, 5th edition, Krishan Vij, page 93.

questions.text: A forensic expert is conducting an autopsy on a highly decomposed body that was recently discovered in a secluded area. The body shows a prominent greenish coloration, especially in the lower abdominal region. The expert is determining the cause of this specific hue as part of the postmortem findings. What is the primary pigment responsible for the greenish discoloration characteristic of putrefaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sulphmethemoglobin

 

Option A:

 

Sulphmethemoglobin is the pigment responsible for the color change in putrefaction. It is formed when hydrogen sulfide (produced by bacterial activity) combines with hemoglobin in the blood, resulting in a greenish discoloration of the tissues. This change is a characteristic feature of the putrefaction process.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. While bilirubin can cause yellowing of tissues, such as in jaundice, it is not the primary pigment associated with the greenish color change seen in putrefaction.

 

Option C. Biliverdin is a green bile pigment produced from the breakdown of hemoglobin, but it is not typically associated with the color change in putrefaction.

 

Option D. Hemosiderin is a pigment that results from the breakdown of hemoglobin and can accumulate in tissues, but it is not responsible for the greenish color seen in putrefaction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mechanism of color change in putrefaction:

 

  1. Direct staining by Hemoglobin (Hb): Lyses of RBCs, releases the Hb. which stains the tissues and vessels producing a reddish-brown coloration which later becomes greenish black.
  2. Staining by Sulph-meth-haemoglobin: Hydrogen sulphides gas produced by decomposing tissues combine with Hb to form sulph-meth-haemoglobin, which stains the tissues and vessels producing a greenish black color.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 164, 170
